Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Stress Quantification Using Extended-Gate Sensing Technology
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of point-of-care device for monitoring stress levels in individuals working in high-stress environments. Psychological stress has important impact on physical health, but detecting and monitoring stress levels is difficult with current methods detecting trace amounts of chemicals in sweat or saliva. However, this is limited due to sensitivity, time, cost, portability, and reproducibility. The proposed technology provides early stress detection and communication through wireless connectivity. Potential users include athletes, military personnel, commercial pilots, and individuals with preexisting health conditions such as hypertension and cardiac dysfunction. The technology could be linked to other stakeholders in industries such as health care, insurance, and clinicians. <br/><br/>This I-Corps project is based on the development of a point-of-care device for measuring cortisol hormone levels in sweat and saliva. The technology uses molecularly imprinted polymers (MIP) for sensing cortisol â€“ a stress biomarker found in body fluids - by electrochemical detection, which is designed to quantitatively monitor and detect cortisol levels in real-time. An extended-gate field-effect transistor (EG-FET) is used as a transducer to detect the electrochemical response of MIPs and to take a direct readout from the sensor. This EG-FET cortisol sensing platform may be easily produced at an industrial scale with miniaturization and automation capabilities. The sensor will aid in low-cost clinical diagnostics by providing real-time visualization of cortisol biomarkers. The goal is to translate this device into an IoT device for wireless data transmission to a smartphone app to monitor cortisol levels.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF ICORP project provided a platform to understand the product-market fit for our device Stress quest. The Stress quest technology allows estimating sweat cortisol levels in individuals who have elevated stress due to work, health conditions or hereditary status. The project provided training and professional development to the team. The outcomes of the project helped us decide that our product is fit for medical and health care diagnoses for patients with cardiac complications. These short interviews with the potential customers provided us the opportunity to serve those most in need. This process saved time and resources by investing them as needed by the customers. Further identification of pains and gains of the customers provided straight forward clear goals in academic research and development plans. I CORP program allowed to fortify an industrial-academic collaboration, resulting in interdisciplinary research that trained students, postdoctoral researchers, and faculty. Provided an opportunity to network with numerous people and institutions for potential collaborations. 

The intellectual property filing has been accelerated during this program. Plans for negotiations with the technology transfer office are being made to commercialize the technology. The customer interviews provided the opportunity to identify potential investors for the proposed technology. The business model is currently focused on the market segment of healthcare biopharma research and development because it is more lucrative than the other commercial or academic segments. The team acquired entrepreneurial skills through the draft of the product roadmap that demonstrates the effective use of technology and business model innovation to advance toward successful commercialization.  

The project is the result of combining interdisciplinary research areas of microfluidics, FET sensor, continuous measurements, bioengineering, and device development. The methodology to develop a technology for any given specific application changed during this program. The opportunity of partnership and networking during this program provided access to numerous information from potential customers and all the way to supply chains. After the I-Corps program, we are now in process of submitting of PFI-TT project proposal to take the technology ahead and find possible commercialization routes. The ICORP program made it possible to test our technology with the consumer market and understand channels, set correct value propositions and business strategies for successful commercialization of our device.


Last Modified: 05/04/2022
Modified by: Jean H Andrian
